p: I have been inspired by reading the digest of your lecture on creatice writing. I only wish we could have more such masterpieces of literature.

And your educational hour on T.V. withMr. Ron Hull most surely brought the flowering of poetry again to the cultural plains of your great State and its neighbors. I can sense the lyric fragrance from here. Surely, the spirit of the world is the better for your leavening.
It was my humble pleasure to read my 14th annual poem to my Colorado Legislature when I was in Denver last month. It seems that all men are thirsting for the "infinite sweetness."
It is my prayer that good health and inspiraiton may long continue your life of "revelation and dedication."
You are a dear, generous-hearted man to write me as you do, and I can assure you that your kindness makes me happy.
I note what you say about reading your fourteenth annual poem to the Colorado Legislature, and I do wish you would send me a copy of that poem.

I have been having a happy time this winter working on my so-called autobiography--so called because I do not know what else to call it! The title is "The Old Man Remembers." I have thirty-seven thousand words written and I should be trhough with the task during this year.
Be sure that I think of you with a warm heart.
